Title:
Haplotype analysis and genetic variability of Togninia minima
from different geographic sources
Abstract:
Togninia minima (anamorph Phaeoacremonium aleophilum) is
one of the main fungi responsible for trunk diseases of grapevines and
other woody hosts worldwide. Public domain sequences of protein coding
genes of isolates from countries in different continents were used as a
resource to evaluate its genetic diversity. Single nucleotide
polymorphisms (SNPs) detected in public sequences of the actin and
partial Î²-tubulin genes were used to assess the genetic variability and
to determine haplotypes of geographic isolates of this species. The
Italian population showed the highest allele number and the highest
number of haplotypes. Most haplotypes were present in more than one
country, except for haplotype 11010 which was found only in Italy and
10111 found only in Canada. Haplotype 11111 was the most conspicuous and
cosmopolitan, being present in six countries and three plant species.
One observed polymorphisms in the non-coding region of the Î²-tubulin
gene could be targeted with allele-specific primers to detect this
particular haplotype.
